Article.ArticleTitle: Ca<sup>2+</sup>-nano starch-lutein endowed 3D printed surimi with antioxidation and mutual reinforcing transmembrane transport mechanisms via hepg2 and caco-2 cells model.

AbstractText: To better enhance printing effects meanwhile casting functionality, antioxidation and absorption of bioactive component in printed Ca<sup>2+</sup>-nano starch (NS)-lutein (L)-surimi were investigated. Results shown that Ca<sup>2+</sup>-NS-L promoted surimi printability due to enhanced gel strength and denser structure. Mixing Ca<sup>2+</sup>-NS-L endowed printed surimi with antioxidation (DPPH, ABTS, hydroxyl radical, Fe<sup>2+</sup> reduction were 42 %, 79 %, 65 %, 0.104 mg·mL<sup>-1</sup>, respectively) due to the ability of lutein with more -OH groups and conjugate bonds to capture free radicals. It also manifested in cellular antioxidation that Ca<sup>2+</sup>-NS-L-surimi regulated the level of Nrf2 to protect gene expression of antioxidases (SOD, CAT, GSH-Px increased by 30-180 %, compared to damaged cells) through keap1-Nrf2-ARE pathway. Additionally, lutein absorption and transportation of Ca<sup>2+</sup>-NS-L-surimi increased by 20 %, compared to NS-L. Possibly, combination of samples and membrane was facilitated by surface hydrophobic, promoting endocytosis. Meanwhile, digestive surimi (peptides) with acidic-alkaline amino acids and negative charges made samples be attracted and moved in bypass parts under electrostatic traction and repulsion (electrostatic domain) to promote transport process. Also, Ca<sup>2+</sup> facilitated CaM expression in membrane and formed Ca<sup>2+</sup> channel by combining with CaM to accelerate entry of samples into cells. Conclusively, Ca<sup>2+</sup>-NS-L both strengthened printability of surimi and antioxidation, promoting application of printed functional surimi.
